Input.threadtitle: How do mapmakers handle continental drift
Input.posts:
With the phenomenal accuracy of modern navigation and mapping systems, how do mappers handle the fact that continents are moving around. Does a location established 20 years ago still have the same exact position on a map or does the map need to be adjusted to be millimeter perfect. I've read that Australia drifts NE at 70mm per year - that's 1.4 metres or 4.5 feet in 20 years That is a significant amount if you're mapping a building or sportsground. How does this work?
Upvotes:
3
I believe that maps are generally updated on a regular basis (every 5-10 years?). In between, any error due to plate tectonics is probably swamped by the imprecision of the mapping and GPS equipment.

0

Upvotes:

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Naime is right - we have lots of different models of the Earth's surface, which are called datums. These can be quite complex, as the Earth's surface is infinitely complicated if you measure its deformations with finer and finer levels of detail. So there are lots of people who work on this problem, constantly trying to work out usable datums for a given area, based on the relevant mapping need. In many cases (e.g. thematic maps showing socioeconomic status), it's not all that important to have the most accurate possible datum behind the scenes. In other cases (surveying very small areas of the Earth, or monitoring those changes over time), it can be absolutely essential as you are in fact dealing with inches rather than hundreds of miles. Time, of course, is another relevant factor, and there are many datums which represent a particular part of the Earth at a particular point in time using detailed survey measurements. So if you repeat that effort for a country every so often, you can begin to account for changes over time.

Input.threadtitle: How do mapmakers handle continental drift
Input.posts:
With the phenomenal accuracy of modern navigation and mapping systems, how do mappers handle the fact that continents are moving around. Does a location established 20 years ago still have the same exact position on a map or does the map need to be adjusted to be millimeter perfect. I've read that Australia drifts NE at 70mm per year - that's 1.4 metres or 4.5 feet in 20 years That is a significant amount if you're mapping a building or sportsground. How does this work?
Upvotes:
3
I believe that maps are generally updated on a regular basis (every 5-10 years?). In between, any error due to plate tectonics is probably swamped by the imprecision of the mapping and GPS equipment.

Upvotes:

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Naime is right - we have lots of different models of the Earth's surface, which are called datums. These can be quite complex, as the Earth's surface is infinitely complicated if you measure its deformations with finer and finer levels of detail. So there are lots of people who work on this problem, constantly trying to work out usable datums for a given area, based on the relevant mapping need. In many cases (e.g. thematic maps showing socioeconomic status), it's not all that important to have the most accurate possible datum behind the scenes. In other cases (surveying very small areas of the Earth, or monitoring those changes over time), it can be absolutely essential as you are in fact dealing with inches rather than hundreds of miles. Time, of course, is another relevant factor, and there are many datums which represent a particular part of the Earth at a particular point in time using detailed survey measurements. So if you repeat that effort for a country every so often, you can begin to account for changes over time.
